messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] one heck of a tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Barry, Good point for clarification... it s not an issue per se if the design enters the seppa dai, but it is when high relief elements of the design are in
messages.messageBody:
Barry,
Good point for clarification... it's not an issue per se if the design enters the seppa dai, but it is when high relief elements of the design are in the seppa dai in a way that would prevent a seppa from fitting flat to the tsuba. The first example I can think of are Nishigaki school tsuba that often have kebori or even sukashi elements of the design entering into the seppa dai. Not a problem for mounting and no questions about them being tsuba, but it does make me think that Kanshiro et. al. were giving some consideration to the tsuba as an individual aesthetic object and not only as an element of a koshirae.

So, this Natsuo in particular -- it looks like the relief of the kanji may be actually reduced in the seppa dai compared to the rest of the web. It's also an even level of relief all of the way around. I think it's "mountable," although it looks like it probably has not been mounted. (Note also that the seppa dai has been drawn in in the preparatory sketches. He didn't forget about it.) I have seen non-Natsuo pieces with a similar amount of "relief" in the seppa dai pass shinsa. What aren't considered tsuba are for example ones with a huge figure sticking up on one side of the seppa dai and nothing on the other.

Another factor in this is that Natsuo's career straddled the edict against wearing swords and the abolition of the samurai class. Generally pieces made after these events won't pass shinsa. However a couple of years ago I asked whether a dated late Natsuo piece would pass or fail, the answer was something like "it's complicated, isn't it." Certainly a fair number of Natsuo guards have never been on a sword. You'll have to decide for yourself if you consider them real sword fittings or not.

Jim



Is this a real tsuba?????????????!!!!! The design goes over the seppa dai!!!

Barry (Cheeky Asshole) Thomas...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] one heck of a tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, just thinking about these numbers which at first sight seem staggering. However when you view it in context the prices paid for works by top end
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,
just thinking about these numbers which at first sight seem staggering. However when you view it in context the prices paid for works by top end masters is still comparatively modest. Going back to the Rai Kunimitsu bought in 2001. $320k would buy a reasonable/modest house in London. But compare that to what you would have to pay for a top work by a 20th. century painter, Luceun Freud currently commands in excess of $1.5million for each new painting. In what other field could collectors still buy works by the worlds leading exponents of their craft throughout history at these prices.
What this means for the rest of us mortals is that very high quality work by recognised masters can still be obtained affordably, not necessarily easily, but within the realms of possibility. I cant think of another field of art where this is the case.

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
Hi Paul,
A lot of the highest level items tend to change hands privately in Japan. I don't know the answer to Matt's question, but the highest tsuba price I personally have heard was ~US$350k. No doubt there are higher prices that I have not heard...
Jim


I think the highest auction price paid for a sword is still the Kiyomaru bought from the Francis Festing collection auction in 1993. That sold for about $450k to a japanese dealer (I think AOI-Art). So assume it sold retail for a lot more. Other close contenders would include some of the blades sold in the Manno collection sale in 2001where a Rai Kunimitsu made approx $320k.

"Matthew E. Hoyle" <matthewhoyle@...> wrote:Anybody know what the world record prices are for 1. a tsuba, 2. a
sword, 3 a koshirae etc ?

Matt

messages.subject: Re: one heck of a tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: I can t say that this particular tsuba rings my chimes, but look on p.112 at the Natsuo menuki pictured in Swords of the Samurai by Harris and Ogasawara.  To
messages.messageBody:
I can't say that this particular tsuba rings my chimes, but look on
p.112 at the Natsuo menuki pictured in "Swords of the Samurai" by
Harris and Ogasawara. To kill for. I understand that Natsuo was so
highly regarded in his own time that he was commissioned to design
the silver one sen piece in the early 1900s. Unfortunately, this
design was, in my opinion, kinda ho-hum traditional (typical curling
dragon) and not in the same ballpark as the referenced menuki. I'm
still trying to find a cheep! cheep! cheep! copy of the book on
Natsuo (was advertised somewhere a few months back at $300, not
exactly chicken feed).

NC
